did.head: Papers Summary
did.abstract: This collection contains various materials Joe Lett Ward, Jr. collected as a member of civic organizations in Waco from the 1950s to the 1970s.

bioghist.head: Biography/Profile
bioghist.p: Joe Lett Ward, Jr. was born in Waco, Texas, on 1916 November 30. Joe, Jr., the son of Joe Ward and Camille Webb, was a fifth generation Wacoan. He graduated from Waco High School in 1933 and later earned a degree in Mechanical Engineering from the University of Texas in 1937. Following his graduation on 1937 October 25 Joe married his high school sweetheart, Martha Harrison.

Ward worked as a petroleum engineer for seven years but returned to Waco after his father passed away. He assumed control of his father's business, the Joe L. Ward Company, and ran the company until he sold it in 1989. Alongside his business endeavors, Ward was involved in civic organizations throughout the Waco community. He was a co-founder of the Ridgewood Country Club in 1946. Ward and his wife Martha were one of fifteen couples to start the St. Alban’s Episcopal Church. He also served on numerous boards including those of the Waco Industrial Foundation, the Waco Business League, and the Citizens National Bank. After serving four years as a member of the Waco city council, his fellow council members appointed him the Mayor of Waco from 1959 to 1960.

As reflected by the materials in this collection, Ward was also an active participant in the civil rights movement in Waco. The city boasted a relatively peaceful integration of its schools and businesses thanks in large part to a nine-man committee chaired by Ward. Operating alongside the Progressive Community Council headed by Reverend Marvin Griffin, these local leaders subtly introduced integration to the community.
Ward passed away on 2009 October 29 at the age of ninety-two.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: The Joe Lett Ward, Jr. papers provide a snapshot of Ward’s community involvement in Waco, Texas. These materials range in chronology from 1953 to 1972 with some undated materials. The documents are in good condition.

The collection is composed of a single series, I. Civic Organizations. The first three folders contain materials related to Ward’s membership in the Waco Association for Good Government. The organization was concerned primarily with local taxes, school programs, and political involvement. Largely falling within a two year time-frame (1953-1954), these materials consist of the organization’s constitution, clippings, correspondence, and rosters.

The next three folders deal with the Community Relations Committee and its predecessor, a subcommittee operating under the Committee of Fifty. Initially, this nine-man committee worked in cooperation with the Progressive Community Council -- which was comprised of prominent African American leaders -- to integrate Waco’s schools, businesses, and work force. The collection contains correspondence, reports, and minutes from the Community Relations Committee.

The final four folders in the collection stem from Ward’s work with the Human Relations Commission. The commission was formed in 1969 July to handle any human rights infringements in Waco, particularly those dealing with race. It was intended to act as a liaison between the community and the city government. These materials include correspondence, reports, minutes, and procedures.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Prior to the latest round of processing, the materials in this collection were housed in three acidic folders. The documents were organized by the committee that produced them. The original titles have been maintained with one exception. The "Inter-Racial Committee," which was initially a subcommittee of the Committee of Fifty, transitioned into the Waco Community Relations Committee under the auspices of the Chamber of Commerce. These materials are now housed in folders labelled "Community Relations Committee."

The original order of the collection has been maintained, although some of the folders were over-stuffed and had to be broken down further according to material type. The collection is currently arranged in a single series, I. Civic Organizations.

Archivist''s Notes: Box # [251], Folder #10 contains a 1963 report produced by the Community Relations Committee. This report recounts, at great length, the history of a subcommittee which helped to integrate Waco's schools and businesses. Prominent Waco leaders, including Joe L. Ward, Jr., Abner McCall, Jack Kultgen, and Harry Provence, worked in conjunction with an African American committee, the Progressive Community Council led by Reverend Marvin Griffin.

bioghist.head: Biography/Profile
bioghist.p: Series I. Civic Organizations, the only series in the Joe Lett Ward, Jr. papers, contains materials from three different Waco civic organizations: the Waco Association for Good Government, the Community Relations Committee, and the Human Relations Commission. The materials -- largely correspondence, minutes, and reports -- are products of Ward's membership in these organizations. Overall, the materials are in good condition.
